note:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Zosyn / Percocet / amiodarone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with hx of CAD s/p RCA stent in ___, HF w/ preserved EF, 
paroxysmal afib now on apixaban, s/p PPM in ___ for tachy-brady 

syndrome, hypothyroidism, HLD, nephrolithiasis, tricuspid 
regurgitation, UTIs, breast cancer s/p mastectomy in ___ who is 
presenting with chest pain. The chest pain is left sided and has 
been coming and going, most recently this morning when she woke 
up from sleep. She has also been having intermittent posterior 
neck pains. She denies shortness of breath, fevers, chills, 
cough, new leg swelling, abdominal pain, n/v/d. She lives with 
her son who has had an influenza like illness for the past two 
days. 
 
In the ED:
Initial vital signs were: T 97.8 81 132/71 18 93% RA 

Exam notable for: Irregularly irregular rhythm, rate 80. Mild 
crackles in the left base, otherwise CTAB. 91% on RA. NTND abd. 
No c/c/e. Mastectomy changes on the left, no new deformities.

Labs were notable for: WBC 10.7, Hct 46.3, ___ 
14.4/54.7/1.3, proBNP 980, Alk Phos 184, AST 51, Trop < 0.01 x2, 
FluA/B PCR negative, BUN/Cr ___, Lactate 1.7, U/A: mod 
bacteria, tr protein

Studies performed include:
___ CXR PA/Lateral: Lower lung volumes compared to the prior 
exam with probable mild pulmonary interstitial edema and 
bibasilar atelectasis, with a retrocardiac pneumonia not 
excluded in the correct clinical setting. A small left pleural 
effusion is also likely present. 

Patient was given: PO Azithromycin 500 mg, IV CTX 1g, Insulin 
10U, D50, PO Spironolactone 25 mg, Apixaban 2.5 mg PO, Verapamil 
120 mg PO, APAP 1 g PO, Furosemide 20 mg PO, K 7.4 w/ repeat 
whole blood K 5.7

Consults: EP, RT 

Vitals on transfer: T 98.1 ___ 20 93% 3L NC 

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient reports she has had three 
days of intermittent chest pain that develops gradually and is 
left-sided. The pain is a dull ache rated ___ and improves 
with Tylenol. She has never had chest pain like this before. She 
denies SOB, cough, dyspnea, abdominal pain, increased lower 
extremity edema, N/V, lightheadedness, orthopnea, or PND. She 
had one occipital headache yesterday which lasted 30 minutes and 
resolved without intervention. She ambulates with a cane and 
uses her right hand. She denies any falls or rashes. Her son 
lives with her and she manages her own medications. She does not 
use a pillbox to plan her weekly medications and will sometimes 
forget to take her home medications. She has not travelled 
recently and denies any sick contacts.

She was hospitalized at ___ approximately two weeks ago 
with abdominal pain and had CT scan which was unremarkable. 
There was concern for Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction and HIDA 
scan was recommended. She deferred HIDA scan until she could 
discuss with her PCP but then her abdominal pain resolved. 
 
Past Medical History:
1. Atrial fibrillation, paroxysmal
2. Sinus node dysfunction, status post ___ Sensia dual
chamber PPM (___), s/p interrogation ___ 
(functioning appropriately)
3. 3vd CAD, s/p RCA stent, ___ 
4. Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
5. Mitral regurgitation, moderate
6. Tricuspid regurgitation, severe
7. Dyslipidemia
8. Breast tubular carcinoma (T1AN0M0) status post excision in
___
9. Prediabetes
10. Hypothyroidism
11. Restrictive lung disease
12. Gouty arthritis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with MI at ___, brother with h/o cardiac
arrest, father with h/o CHF; brother with h/o afib

=========================

HEENT: NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI, sclera anicteric, MMM, good dentition 

NECK: JVD elevated slightly above level of clavicle
CARDIAC: RRR, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
CHEST: left-sided tenderness to palpation at level of 5th rib, 
reproducible 
LUNGS: Bilateral lower lobe crackles, unlabored respirations, no 
wheezes or rhonchi, decreased breath sounds bilaterally
ABDOMEN: soft, non-distended, no tenderness to palpation, no 
organomegaly, no rebound or guarding
EXTREMITIES: trace lower extremity edema to the mid-shin 
bilaterally
SKIN: warm, well-perfused, multiple ecchymoses on forearms 
bilaterally 
NEUROLOGIC: A/Ox3, moving all four extremities with purpose

CARDIAC: Irreg rhythm, normal rate, no murmurs
LUNGS: CTAB, no wheezes or rhonchi, decreased breath sounds at
bases bilaterally
ABDOMEN: soft, non-distended, no tenderness to palpation
EXTREMITIES: trace lower extremity edema 
NEUROLOGIC: A/Ox3, CN III-XII grossly intact, moving all four
extremities with purpose

RELEVANT STUDIES
=========================
CHEST XRAY ___
Lower lung volumes compared to the prior exam with probable mild 
pulmonary
interstitial edema and bibasilar atelectasis, with a 
retrocardiac pneumonia
not excluded in the correct clinical setting.  A small left 
pleural effusion
is also likely present.

TTE ___
The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is moderately 
dilated. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and 
regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). Tissue 
Doppler imaging suggests a normal left ventricular filling 
pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). The right ventricular cavity is 
moderately dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The 
diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are 
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but 
aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is 
seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild to 
moderate (___) mitral regurgitation is seen. Severe [4+] 
tricuspid regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the 
severity of tricuspid regurgitation may be significantly 
UNDERestimated.] [In the setting of at least moderate to severe 
tricuspid regurgitation, the estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure may be underestimated due to a very high right atrial 
pressure.] There is a trivial pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated, mildly hypokinetic right 
ventricle in the setting of severe tricuspid regurgitation and 
at least mild pulmonary hypertension. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the 
right ventricle is larger and contracts less vigorously. The 
severity of tricuspid regurgitation has likely increased 
further. 

RUQ ULTRASOUND ___
No findings to explain the patient's abdominal pain.  No acute 
cholecystitis
or cholelithiasis.

CT CHEST ___. Left lower lobe and lingular atelectasis/consolidation.  
Small to moderate
left and trace right pleural effusions.
2. Mild interlobular septal thickening involving the left lung 
may be related
to atelectasis or represent mild asymmetric interstitial 
pulmonary edema.
3. Cardiomegaly with enlargement of the main pulmonary trunk, 
which can be
seen in the context of pulmonary arterial hypertension, in the 
appropriate
clinical setting.
4. Compression deformities in the thoracic spine as described 
above.

CHEST XRAY ___
In comparison with the study of ___, there are improved 
lung volumes. 
Again there is substantial enlargement of the cardiac silhouette 
with pacer
leads extending to the right atrium and right ventricle. 
Relatively mild
vascular congestion.  Retrocardiac opacification is consistent 
with volume
loss in left lower lobe and probable small effusion.
Compression deformities in the thoracic spine are better 
demonstrated on the
CT study of ___.

WITH SKIN

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history heart failure 
with preserved ejection fraction, coronary artery disease s/p 
RCA stent, paroxysmal afib, tachy-brady syndrome s/p PPM in 
___, and hypothyroidism who presented with chest pain, felt to 
be musculoskeletal. She was found to have hypoxemic respiratory 
failure, felt secondary to pneumonia and HFpEF exacerbation. She 
was treated with levofloxacin and increased Lasix, with 
resolution of hypoxia. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=========================
# Hypoxemic respiratory failure
# Community acquired pneumonia 
# Acute on chronic HFpEF: 
Patient presented with new oxygen requirement on admission, felt 
secondary pneumonia and acute on chronic HFpEF after patient 
received IV fluid in the ED. She was treated with a 7 day course 
of levofloxacin [___] and diuresis with IV Lasix followed 
by increased dose of PO Lasix. At discharge, she was euvolemic 
on exam and breathing comfortably on room air. Her ambulatory 
oxygen saturation ws 91-93%. She will follow up with cardiology 
and pulmonology as an outpatient with repeat chest xray to 
ensure resolution of pleural effusion and consolidation.

# AFib with RVR: 
# Tachy-brady syndrome: 
On admission, pacemaker interrogation was notable for several 
episodes of afib with RVR. She had episodes of Afib with RVR 
during admission as well, likely secondary to pneumonia and 
volume overload as above. She remained hemodynamically stable 
and denied any symptoms during these episodes other than 
occasional "head heaviness". She was unaware of most of these 
episodes. Given prior bradycardia and hypotension with more 
aggressive rate control, she was continued on home verapamil and 
dose-reduced apixaban (CHADS-VASC 3). She will follow up with 
cardiology as an outpatient. 

# Musculoskeletal chest pain
Patient presented with three days of intermittent chest pain 
that improved with Tylenol. Her chest pain was focal, 
left-sided, and reproducible with palpation, most consistent 
with musculoskeletal pain. EKG showed no evidence of ischemia, 
and troponin/CKMB were negative x 2. Chest pain resolved during 
admission. Her home atorvastatin and apixaban were continued. 
She is not on aspirin at home to decrease bleeding risk.

# GERD
Patient complained of burning pain in epigastric area with 
eating, consistent with GERD. She was started on omeprazole 20mg 
and Maalox prn, with improvement in symptoms. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 
============================
# Intermittent RUQ pain:
Patient had RUQ pain intermittently with eating. RUQ ultrasound 
was unremarkable. She had a similar episode several weeks ago, 
which was felt to be sphincter of odi dysfunction. Patient may 
benefit from HIDA scan as outpatient if pain continues. 

# Hypothyroidism:
TSH 4.1. Continued home levothyroxine.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
==========================
DISCHARGE WEIGHT: 59.2 kg (130.51 lb) 

[] Started on omeprazole and Maalox prn for GERD.
[] Spironolactone was held at discharge given hyperkalemia on 
admission. Please ___ as appropriate.
[] Please monitor patient's weight and volume exam, and adjust 
Lasix dosing as needed. 
[] Patient will follow up with cardiology in 3 weeks. 
[] Patient needs repeat chest xray and follow up with 
pulmonology in 6 weeks to assess improvement in pleural effusion 
and consolidation. 
[] Patient may benefit from HIDA scan as outpatient if RUQ pain 
continues.

Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY
# Hypoxemic respiratory failure
# Community acquired pneumonia 
# Acute on chronic heart failure with preserved ejection 
fraction
# Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
# Tachy-brady syndrome
# Musculoskeletal chest pain
# GERD

SECONDARY:
# Intermittent RUQ pain
# Hypothyroidism

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital because you were having chest 
pain. 

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- You had blood tests which showed that your chest pain was not 
coming from your heart. The chest pain was probably coming from 
the muscles and cartilage in your chest. This was treated with 
Tylenol and lidocaine patches.
- You were diagnosed with a pneumonia and a flare of your heart 
failure. You were treated with antibiotics, extra Lasix (the 
water pill), and extra oxygen.
- You had some stomach pain with eating. This might be caused by 
acid reflux. You were started on a medicine called omeprazole 
and Maalox as needed for this. 

WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?
- Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ to make a 
follow up appointment this coming week. 
- You will need to see the lung doctors and get another chest 
xray in 6 weeks. The lung doctors are working to set up an 
appointment for you. If you don't hear from them by ___ 
___, please call them at ___ to make an appointment. 
- Please take all your medicines as described in this paperwork. 

- Please keep all your follow up appointments as listed below. 
- Please weigh yourself every morning. Call your doctor if your 
weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Your weight at discharge was 130 
pounds. 

It was a pleasure to participate in your care. We wish you all 
the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
